resources.string: The Busch Engineering, Science, and Technology West Residence Hall, commonly referred to as just "BEST", will become your home away from home for the next four weeks. The rooms are obscenely luxurious and spacious for college dorms as the building was constructed recently in 2011. Each room houses two scholars and is connected by a bathroom to an adjacent room. This room-bathroom-room structure is called a suite. Make sure to get along well with your roommate and suitemates because you will work on various projects, such as robotics, together as a two or four person group. Of course you should make friends with everyone at GSET, not just your suitemates!

Abbreviated as SERC (pron. S-ER-K), this building will be where the GSET orientation is held for both parents and scholars. During the orientation, you will meet the hardworking individuals behind GSET, including but not limited to Dean Rosen, Dean Antoine, and your gorgeous RTAs. When not serving as an orientation center, SERC is the location of math and computer science courses. Make sure not to talk in the halls as summer courses are ongoing. Perhaps most importantly, this building is a haven for all those that love to live in subzero temperatures. The air conditioning here is turned on to max 24/7. This will be your biggest blessing after walking in the Piscatway heat all the way from BEST (approx. 10000 miles) to attend classes.

The Busch Dining Hall will be where you eat for the majority of your meals (except catered meals, which are held at BEST). Make sure to have your meal card ready when you get to the doors.
For breakfast, there are scrambled eggs with a choice of protein (often sausage or bacon), and a side of potatoes (often in the form of hash browns or tater tots). You can accompany your breakfast with a lovely side of fresh fruits from the fruit bar, or if you are feeling particularly peckish, indulge in an unlimited supply of donuts.
For lunch,
There are no classes held in the campus center; however savvy RTAs will lead their groups through this air conditioned building in order to avoid the heat.

Abbreviated as CAIT (pron. K-AY-T), this building is the center for civil engineering. Occasionally, keynote speakers will present here. If you do take an architecture course, it will most likely take place in CAIT.

Shortened to CoRE (pron. K-OR), the Computing Research and Education Building is the main building for computer science. Currently, no classes are held in this building, but computer programming research project groups often meet their mentors here.

Several classes and projects take place in the Engineering Building. The bountiful laboratories and tools available in this building make it a catch-all for various research projects and classes. If you are in a pharmacy, chemistry, or materials engineering class, expect to spend at least 6 hours here each week.
